ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Collapsed ear canals
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Significant air-bone gap at 4000 Hz with normal immittance results; gap resolved and thresholds improved when retested with insert earphones.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: False air-bone gap (calibration/RETFL artifact)
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: 4000 Hz air-bone gaps can occur due to calibration standards (RETFLs), but the magnitude and resolution with inserts point to collapse.

ranked_differential_diagnosis.label: Mixed hearing loss
ranked_differential_diagnosis.rationale_short: Suggested by air-bone gap but ruled out by normal tympanometry and acoustic reflexes.

ordered_list.rationale_short: Baseline assessment of hearing sensitivity using standard TDH-50 headphones.
Assessment of speech reception threshold and word recognition ability.
Evaluation of middle ear function to investigate the cause of the air-bone gap.
Further assessment of retrocochlear and middle ear function.
Retest of high frequencies with insert earphones to rule out collapsed ear canals.

expected_interpretations_by_visit.collective_interpretation: Initial testing with supra-aural headphones revealed high-frequency sensorineural hearing loss with a suspicious 25 dB air-bone gap at 4000 Hz bilaterally. Immittance testing was normal, ruling out middle ear pathology. Retesting air conduction with insert earphones resulted in significantly improved thresholds (15–25 dB) and elimination of the air-bone gap, confirming the diagnosis of collapsed ear canals.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.result_summary: Normal hearing 250-1000 Hz sloping to moderate/moderately severe loss 4000-8000 Hz. Significant 25 dB air-bone gap at 4000 Hz bilaterally.

tests.name: Speech audiometry
tests.result_summary: SRTs 25 dB HL bilaterally; WRS 92% bilaterally.

tests.name: Acoustic reflexes
tests.result_summary: Normal thresholds 500-4000 Hz; negative reflex decay.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry (Retest)
tests.result_summary: With insert earphones, AC thresholds improved by 15-25 dB at 4000-8000 Hz, eliminating the air-bone gap.

proposed_items: Use insert earphones for all future audiometric testing to prevent ear canal collapse.
counseling_actions: Explain that the hearing test discrepancy was caused by the headphones pressing on the ear canals (collapsed canals) rather than a medical problem.
Discuss the high-frequency hearing loss and its impact on telephone communication.
Advise the patient to discuss her nightly dizziness symptoms in detail with the otologist.

red_flags_present: Dizziness (spinning/lightheaded) increasing in frequency and waking patient from sleep

escalation.rationale_short: Patient is already scheduled for an otology appointment to evaluate dizziness and hearing loss.

follow_up_plan.objective: Monitor hearing status and manage dizziness symptoms.

expected_outcome: Pure-tone audiometry (retest with inserts) revealed an improvement in air conduction thresholds of 20 dB HL at 4000 and 6000 Hz and 25 dB HL at 8000 Hz in the right ear.
Pure-tone audiometry (retest with inserts) revealed an improvement in air conduction thresholds of 25 dB HL at 4000 Hz, 20 dB HL at 6000 Hz, and 15 dB HL at 8000 Hz in the left ear.
The 4000 Hz air–bone gap disappeared when insert earphones were used, confirming the presence of collapsed ear canals.
